Award.AwardTitle: Nanochemical Control of Polymorphism in Transition Metal Chalcogenides
Award.AbstractNarration:
NON-TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
Many useful and important technologies rely on materials that contain compounds formed by combining transition metals with sulfur, selenium, or tellurium. The properties of these so-called metal chalcogenides depend on their crystal structures, or the arrangements of the atoms that comprise them. Some useful metal chalcogenide systems can form several closely related crystal structures, and even small differences in how the atoms are arranged can dramatically influence their properties. Therefore, in order to control and tune the properties of metal chalcogenides, it is important to understand how to control their crystal structures. With the support of the Solid State and Materials Chemistry program, the research team is investigating chemical methods that precisely target the formation of one particular crystal structure in metal chalcogenide systems where multiple crystal structures are known. Nanoscale crystals of metal chalcogenides have unique characteristics that enable these studies, including the ability to facilitate chemical reactions that manipulate important features of their crystal structures. The knowledge gained from this project is useful for producing new materials that are relevant for applications in catalysis, electronics, and magnetism. This project is providing a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students with multi-disciplinary training in research, communication, project management, and outreach. A formal collaboration with an undergraduate research group further expands both training and research opportunities. In addition, the entire research team is engaged in the development of news clips and social media content for showcasing to the general public the diversity of materials-focused research and researchers.

TECHNICAL ABSTRACT
Transition metal chalcogenides comprise an important class of inorganic solids that enable a wide range of applications, particularly as nanoscale materials. Underpinning their applications is the ability to synthetically achieve precisely controlled features, including crystal structure and morphology, that directly impact properties. In this project, the research team is identifying and understanding the reaction parameters, reaction pathways, and materials characteristics that lead to the predictable and selective formation of stable and metastable metal chalcogenide polymorphs. The primary materials systems being studied include cobalt, iron, and manganese sulfides and molybdenum tellurides made using both direct synthesis methods and nanoparticle chemical transformation reactions. This new knowledge is being used to overcome significant chemical bottlenecks in the formation of several high-value materials targets for emerging applications. This project is providing a diverse group of graduate and undergraduate students with multi-disciplinary training in research, communication, project management, and outreach. The project includes a formal collaboration with an undergraduate research group and also engages students in the development of news clips and social media content for showcasing to the general public the diversity of materials-focused research and researchers.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Nanoscale metal sulfides, selenides, and tellurides -- collectively referred to as metal chalcogenides -- are important for many applications, including batteries and light-driven catalysts. To study and use nanoscale metal chalcogenides for these and other applications, it is important to first understand how to make them. This project focused on developing new chemical capabilities for making two classes of nanoscale metal chalcogenides -- transition metal dichalcogenides (TMDs) and cation-exchanged metal sulfide nanoparticles -- to provide new nanostructure design tools that are relevant for many applications. This project also provided multi-disciplinary scientific training and professional development opportunities for a diverse team of students, including development of a regional undergraduate research network involving students and faculty from local colleges having complementary interests in the synthesis, characterization, and properties of metal chalcogenide nanoparticles and related materials.

TMDs are two-dimensional materials that can be made as nanosheets, and they have unique properties that depend on how thick the nanosheets are. Most methods to make TMD nanosheets produce thin films or other surface-bound materials. Colloidal TMD nanostructures, which are small nanoparticles of TMDs that can be dispersed in liquids, are desirable for some applications that require larger amounts of material or that benefit from solution processing. This project provided new chemical capabilities for making several important types of colloidal TMD nanoparticles, as well as new understanding of how they form and how their compositions and structures can be controlled. These TMD nanoparticles can now be explored for their novel catalytic properties and for their ability to grow other materials on their surfaces that can enhance their properties.

The properties and applications of metal chalcogenide nanoparticles depend on the identity of the metal and the chalcogen, as well as the crystal structure, shape, size, and whether or not the metal chalcogenide is connected to any other materials that modify it. This project also provided chemical guidelines for simultaneously controlling all of these features for several metal sulfide materials. Using a process called "cation exchange," the copper cations in colloidal copper sulfide nanoparticles could be replaced with other cations, which are dissolved in solution, to produce related nanoparticles having different metals but the same crystal structure, shape, and size. When only some of the copper cations were replaced, the resulting partial cation exchange reactions produced a junction, or interface, between the new metal sulfide and the leftover copper sulfide -- all within the original nanoparticle. This project developed capabilities to carry out multiple partial cation exchange reactions to progressively convert a copper sulfide nanoparticle into a library of much more complex nanoparticles, each containing several different metal sulfides. Useful chemical principles, including crystal structure relationships, were uncovered to guide this process to allow it to be carried out rationally and predictably. In this way, it became possible to design and then make a library of complex multi-segment nanoparticles with different shapes. Cation exchange reactions were also used to produce new metal sulfides having crystal structures and compositions that typically do not form. These chemical design capabilities can now be used to create many new types of designer nanoparticles for diverse applications.
